title: East Harptree Woods Walk Route

images.title: Track into East Harptree Woods by Sarah Charlesworth, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Track into East Harptree Woods

images.title: Chris Heaton / Smitham Chimney
images.caption: Smitham Chimney is 70ft high and made of brick & stone. The scene here in the 1850s would have been one of intense industrial activity. Lead was smelted (mainly for use as shot for guns). The chimney is the last of its kind in South-West England.

images.title: Clock at the bottom of Church Lane, East Harptree by Sarah Charlesworth, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Clock at the bottom of Church Lane, East Harptree village.

images.title: Aqueduct, Harptree Combe by Vince Simmonds, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Aqueduct, Harptree Combe. You will pass this ruined structure if you walk down through the Combe to the woods from the village.

images.title: Farmland above East Harptree by David Purchase, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Farmland above East Harptree. A view of the countryside between the woods and the village.

description: This walk explores East Harptree Woods near the village of East Harptree in Somerset. The village is located in the Mendips Hills overlooking the Valley of the River Chew. You can find the woods just to the south west of the settlement. There's a public car park at the woods or you can stroll down from the village through Harptree Combe. At the site there are a series of peaceful woodland trails leading to the Smitham Chimney . The photogenic 19th century structure is a reminder of the lead mining history of the area. It is a Grade II listed building and is an added attraction to this quiet woodland area. The Monarch's Way runs past the eastern side of the woods. You could pick up this trail and follow it north to neighbouring Compton Martin to extend the walk.  Here you will find a noteworthy  Norman church, an historic 16th century pub and the picturesque millpond which is the source of the Congresbury Yeo River.
